response.answer_text: Because we appointed the US to be our prime enemy. Here’s the rationale. History After the collapse of Communism, there was time when America and Russia were friends, and sometimes even allies. In the former Yugoslavia, the two countries cooperated in peace-keeping operations. When Al Qaeda attacked New York, Putin even allowed the US to open an American base on the Russian soil in Ulianovsk. It was first in 2007 that Putin started to describe America in hostile terms, and in 2014 he moved them into the enemy category. On the opposite side, when contenders to the American presidency during the electoral campaigns called us enemies, the winners, Obama and Trump, ridiculed them. In their world, Russia was too marginal to be considered an enemy. Before the controversy around the election of Trump, it was up to us, Russians, to consider the relationship with America as enmity or friendship. Why did we choose to become enemies? Enemy of our choosing It’s largely a product of internal Russian politics. President Putin came to power with a mandate from the oligarchical clans to (1) protect the results of the flawed privatization in the 1990s, and (2) integrate Russian state-oligarchical Capitalism into the global Western power structures on equal terms. Putin violated this mandate on the first point—i.e., he redistributed wealth from “old” oligarchs to new ones, his pals, aides and allies—and failed totally on the second one. This predictably created increasing tensions within the ruling elite. That came to surface during Medvedev’s presidency, and created a clear and present threat to Putin’s rule in 2011–2013. Putin’s answer to this was consolidation of the elites on a nationalist, revisionist, anti-Western ideological foundation. In order to do that, President Putin used three confluent factors: The inconclusive end of the Cold War that failed to provide a new long-term security arrangement for Europe and the rest of the world on Western termsThe legacy of Soviet strategic policy thinking that considered the American military presence in Europe as the singular fundamental threat to our countryThe windfall of oil proceeds that gave Russia the financial backbone in the confrontation with the WestPoint of no return The election of Trump and the expectations around it in Russia marked a hope in Russia in 2016–2017 of returning to the early Putin’s “Londongrad project” through a compromise with Trump on the elements of a New Yalta deal. However, the recent frenzy in our loyalist media and the increasingly bizarre statements of Russia’s foreign office in the wake of the Skripal poisoning and Syrian chemical weapons controversy make me think that both projects are now laid dead by Putin. Which means we must prepare for enmity with the US for the rest of his presidency, at least. Pictures below are from the art exhibition in Moscow “Putin’s Universe”. The hydra on the painting to the right sports heads marked “EU”, “Japan”, “Sanctions”, “Canada”. The chopped-off head is marked “USA”. The bearded man to the left strangled by Putin sports a baseball hat with the word “Terror”.
